title.title: Letter from James M. Haynes to Mississippi Governor John J. Pettus; August 3, 1861

note.p: John Jones Pettus was Mississippi's governor during the first three years of the Civil War.

Born in Wilson County, Tennessee, on October 9, 1813, Pettus moved to Limestone County, Alabama, as a child. In 1835, he moved to Mississippi and eventually began a law practice in Scooba, Mississippi. He married Permelia Winston in the 1840s. She passed away in 1857, and in 1861 Pettus married Susan Hewell.

Pettus began pursuing a political career in the mid-1840s, first serving as a state representative for Kemper County. He won a state Senate election in 1848 and by 1853 had risen to president of the Mississippi Senate. Then, in January 1854, Governor Henry S. Foote resigned in protest before Governor-elect John J. McRae was inaugurated. Pettus’ position in the Senate placed him next in line to fill the governor’s vacancy, and he was sworn in as Mississippi’s interim executive on January 7, 1854. He served in that role for only three days, before McRae was inaugurated on January 10.

Pettus won the governor’s election in 1859. By that time, he had become a notable secessionist. He advocated for the creation of an independent Confederacy dedicated to preserving slavery. When Abraham Lincoln was elected president in 1860, Pettus called forth a special legislative session in Mississippi and pressed state representatives to hold a secession convention. His efforts succeeded, as such convention assembled in January 1861 and voted in support of secession, declaring the State of Mississippi out of the Union. Pettus won reelection for governor in 1861 and served until his term ended in 1863. Mississippi’s Constitution had a two-term limit for the governor’s office, leaving Pettus unable to run again. He took a commission as a colonel in the Mississippi State Troops and served until the end of the war. Shortly thereafter, Pettus moved to Arkansas. He applied for a presidential pardon according to President Andrew Johnson’s Reconstruction policies, but was denied three times.
Pettus died of pneumonia on January 25, 1867. He is buried in Flat Bayou Cemetery, Jefferson County, Arkansas.
(Wikipedia; FindaGrave)
John Jones Pettus belonged to the following social groups:

note.p: Absolom Madden West was a Confederate general, a Mississippi politician, railroad executive, and vice presidential candidate. Born in Alabama in 1818, West moved to Mississippi around 1837 to establish a plantation with property he acquired from federal land grants. He entered Mississippi state politics as a Whig and won a seat in the Mississippi Senate in 1847. He married Caroline O. Glover in the 1840s and the couple had four surviving children, born between 1849 and 1862.

In 1853, he took an office job with the new Mississippi Central Railroad, gaining experience not only in railroad development but corporate and logistical operations. As a Whig, West originally opposed secession. However, after Mississippi left the Union in 1861, during the secession crisis that split the country following Abraham Lincon’s election to president in November 1860, West offered his loyalty and services to the state. He was promoted a brigadier general in the Mississippi state militia, and helped raised a regiment of volunteers. Recognizing his skill and experience in administrative and logistical work, state officials appointed him to several different managerial roles, such as quartermaster general, paymaster general, and commissary general of the militia. He made recommendations to the state legislature to improve the accounting of funds, and was the only state officer to have his accounting books in order and submitted at the end of the war.

West took the role of president over the Mississippi Central Railroad around 1864. He remained in that position until around the end of the war, then returned to state politics—again serving in the Mississippi Senate—after the Illinois Central purchased the Mississippi Central. West was elected to the U.S. House of Representatives during the early effort by the Mississippi government in 1865 to earn readmission to the Union under President Andrew Johnson’s lenient Reconstruction plan. However, he was among the Mississippi delegation refused seats in Congress when Republicans in Washington, D.C., objected to Mississippi’s “Black Codes”—a series of highly discriminatory laws passed in the summer of 1865 to restrict the civil rights of African Americans.

West became involved in labor rights during Reconstruction, helping form a branch of the National Labor Union. Reentering the Mississippi Senate in the early 1870s, around 1876 he broke away from the Democratic Party and joined the emerging “Greenback Party”—an independent, anti-monopoly political party. It united many state-level politicians in the north and the south on economic matters, namely the expansion of paper currency believed to help farmers and small businesses. Attesting to the party’s ability to bring former enemies together, the party’s national convention in 1884 nominated former Union general Benjamin Butler (who had been despised within the Confederacy during his occupation of New Orleans during the Civil War) for its presidential candidate and the former Confederate militia general West as vice president. The party polled only a 1.7% of the popular vote in 1884.
West’s wife Caroline died in 1889 after a long bout of poor health. He died five years later, in 1894. The couple is buried in Hill Crest Cemetery in Holly Springs, Mississippi.
(Wikipedia; FindaGrave)
Absalom Madden West belonged to the following social groups:
Madison McAfee was a political figure in Mississippi, who ran for governor in 1861 and served as the state’s quartermaster general during the Civil War.

Born in Lawrence, Mississippi in 1818, McAfee served a public auditor in Mississippi during the late 1850s. Shortly after Mississippi declared its secession from the Union in early 1861, McAfee received an appointment as quartermaster general for the state’s military. As part of the “Military Board” overseeing the Mississippi militia, McAfee clashed with Governor John J. Pettus. He ran for governor as a moderate Democrat against Pettus in a contentious election in the fall of 1861. However, in September, before the election, McAfee stepped away from the gubernatorial race, reportedly citing his desire to avoid a highly partisan political battle in the midst of the war. McAfee died the following year, 1862.

(The Weekly Mississippian, Jackson, MS, July 20, 1859; The American Citizen, Canton, MS, September 21, 1861; Robert W. Dubay, “Mississippi,” The Confederate Governors, ed. W. Buck Yearns, 118-119; Dunbar Rowland, The Official and Statistical Register of the State of Mississippi, 1908, 31, 148, 424)
Madison McAfee belonged to the following social groups:
James M. Haynes was a law enforcement officer, military officer, and businessman in Mississippi in the mid-nineteenth century.

Born around 1823 in Virginia, Haynes moved to Lexington, Mississippi, as a young man. By 1850 he was deputy sheriff of Holmes County, eventually rising to the office of sheriff by 1860. During the Civil War, he volunteered for military service, and accepted a commission as a quartermaster officer. At the end of the Civil War, Haynes briefly worked with a commission merchant business in New Orleans, Louisiana, but relocated to Texas by 1870, settling in Brownsville. He passed away in 1886.

(1850 U.S. Census for Lexington, Holmes County, Mississippi; U.S. Register of Civil, Military, and Naval Service, 1863-1959, Ancestry.com; The Lexington Advertiser, Lexington, MS, March 30, 1860, and September 13, 1867; Geneanet Community Trees Index, Ancestry.com; Charles W. L. Hall, Coopers Adjutants…And The Unsung Heroics and Deeds of Clerks in Gray, 105)
James M. Haynes belonged to the following social groups:

Located in Attala County, Kosciusko was located in 1834 under the name Paris and was renamed Kosciusko in 1839. Kosciusko serves as the county seat. (Wikipedia; Rowland, Mississippi, 1004; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)
Located in Choctaw County, Bankston was founded as early as 1848. Bankston is a deserted town with few or no remaining inhabitants. (Wikipedia)

catDesc.note:
Categories:
Businesses -- Commerce & Trade
Businesses -- Extraction, Manufacturing, & Production

gloss.p: Cotton is a native plant to the Americas which produces puffy bolls of soft white fibers used for clothing and fabric production since the prehistoric era. There are two main species of cotton—distinguished primarily by their fiber length. Short staple cotton has shorter fibers but can grow across a broader geographical area in the southern United States. Long staple cotton is considered by many to produce higher quality, softer fibers, but is more tropical and frost sensitive, isolating it to the warm coastal areas of the lower south.

Long staple cotton became a highly prized cash crop for seventeenth and eighteenth century farmers in the lower south, particularly along the South Carolina and Georgia coastline. Sea Island cotton was carefully cultivated and developed by planters who imported long fiber plants from Central and South America to improve the quality. This lucrative crop was labor intensive, requiring laborers to pick the bolls by hand—a task increasingly given to enslaved people. Once collected, the cotton bolls had to be processed to remove seeds so the fibers could be spun into thread and the seeds used for planting or for cottonseed oil production. Early American cotton planters used a simple cotton gin (or cotton engine), originally designed in India in the fifth century, to mechanically separate seeds from the long staple fibers. This basic gin did not work with short fiber cotton. Because of this, short staple cotton was not a popular crop during the colonial era, as the manual labor required to separate seeds from the bolls was time and cost prohibitive.

This changed in the 1790s when inventor Eli Whitney designed a new cotton gin that could efficiently separate seeds from short staple cotton. The design immediately made the heartier short fiber cotton plant a viable cash crop and spurred the expansion of cotton farming—on large plantations to small farms—across the south. The pursuit of new farmland for cotton production drove westward migration, the displacement of Native Americans in the south, and helped the creation of new states, including Alabama and Mississippi. The cotton gin only mechanized the processing of cotton. Harvesting the cotton bolls was still done by hand (machine harvesting would not become prevalent until the twentieth century). Therefore, the expansion of cotton farms across the south brought with it the rapid growth of slavery.

Planters produced 750,000 bales of cotton in 1830. Twenty years later, in 1850, the south produced 2.85 million bales annually. In 1860, American planters delivered 5.3 million bales. At 400 pounds per bale, the United States produced more than two billion pounds of cotton in 1860. The crop dominated southern agriculture and made the United States one of the world’s top exporters of the product, chiefly to textile mills in England and France. At the eve of the Civil War, southern politicians believed the importance of the south’s cotton exports gave it diplomatic leverage over European powers. Senator James Hammond of South Carolina famously quipped that “no power on earth dares to make war upon [cotton]. Cotton is king.”

Southern secessionist ideas of cotton’s diplomatic influence during the Civil War proved misplaced. The decrease of cotton exports, due to the Union naval blockade and even efforts by Confederate politicians to create international demand by burning 2.5 million bales of southern cotton, failed to coerce England or France to formally side with the Confederacy or make war upon the Union. Strong cotton crops in the 1850s had led to a surplus of cotton in Europe, and Great Britain chose to find alternate sources of cotton (such as India and Egypt) rather than engage embroil itself in the American Civil War. Some desperate southern farmers even traded with federal officials, and occupying Union forces confiscated cotton crops and transferred them north to textile manufacturers in the northeast.

After the Civil War, cotton production remained an important agricultural interest for the south. The abolition of slavery did not end the role African Americans played as the primary source of labor for cotton harvesting. Freed peoples grew their own cotton crops as tenant farmers or sharecroppers across the south through the late nineteenth century, resulting in the south continually exporting millions of bales each year. Although a lucrative crop, the cotton farmers—white and black—rarely enjoyed wealth from their labor, due to periodic market crashes and competition. Cotton farming did not substantially change until the early twentieth century with the advent of mechanized cotton harvesters. (Wikipedia; census.gov; Eugene R. Dattel, “Cotton and the Civil War,” Mississippi History Now; “Cotton Sector at a Glance,” Economic Research Service, U.S. Department of Agriculture)

catDesc.term: Cotton Manufacturing & Sales--Mississippi Manufacturing Company (Choctaw County, Miss.)

gloss.p: Located in Choctaw, Mississippi, the Mississippi Manufacturing Company was chartered by the state in 1848 to process cotton, flour, grain, wool, and timber. The Mississippi Manufacturing Company was the state's largest and most profitable textile manufacturer, creating a company town in Bankston. The Mississippi Manufacturing Company almost exclusively employed white men and women. During the Civil War, the Company made Confederate troop uniforms, and Union troops burned down the Company's building in January of 1865. (Encyclopedia of Mississippi)

Military discharges are formal notices issued to members of the armed forces confirming that they are formally released from their obligation to serve. During the American Civil War, soldiers and officers were honorably discharged from service for a variety of reasons, including severe injuries or diseases, resignation, or their unit mustering out, among other reasons. Those who were honorably discharged were eligible to reenlist or receive veterans' benefits after the war. (Wikipedia)

The end of the Civil War, which began with the surrender of Confederate forces at Appomattox Court House in April 1865, led to the largest number of military discharges. Once captured, Confederate forces became prisoners of war and parole did not formally discharge them from Confederate armies. As Union and Confederate troops demobilized, authorities moved to formally discharge troops. On June 6, 1865, U.S. President Andrew Johnson ordered the discharge of most remaining Confederate prisoners of war, a process that took two months to complete. For the significant number of soldiers who returned home without going through formal discharge processes, they had difficulty proving they had been honorably discharged from the military, which was a core requirement for many veterans' benefits and membership in veterans' associations. (Caroline E. Janney, Ends of War, p. 217)

catDesc.note:
Categories:
Military Units -- Federal Level: Confederate States Military

gloss.p: The Confederate Army was the military land force of the Confederate States of America during the American Civil War. Known also as the Confederate States Army or Southern Army, it was established by the Provisional Confederate Congress in February 1861 and fell under the authority of Confederate President Jefferson Davis. Modeled after the U.S. Army of the 19th century, the Confederate Army technically fell into two categories: a small regular army of professional officers and soldiers (the Army of the Confederate States of America) and a much larger, temporary force of citizen soldiers intended to exist only for the duration of the war (the Provisional Army of the Confederate States). In reality, the Confederacy’s regular army never fully developed and the overwhelming majority of Confederate soldiers served in the provisional force. The distinction between the two played little role during military operations and all were generally considered to be part of the overall Confederate Army.

As many as 1,000,000 soldiers served in the Confederate Army between 1861 and 1865, although not all at one time. Most were volunteers, however, the Confederate government instituted a conscription (or draft) in April 1862—the first in U.S. or Confederate history—to increase the size of the Confederacy’s military force and encourage voluntary enlistment. The government passed two more conscription acts over the next two years. More than ten percent of the men who served in Confederate ranks were drafted.

Over ninety percent of soldiers in the Confederate Army were native-born white men. Nine percent were foreign-born white men. Several Native American units—particularly from the Cherokee, Creek, and Choctaw tribes—served within the Confederate military, especially in the trans-Mississippi theatre. The Confederate military heavily relied upon the forced labor of enslaved African Americans for building fortifications and carrying out menial tasks, and the Confederate government did not formally allow African Americans (free or slave) to join the army until a last minute desperate measure passed the Confederate Congress in March 1865, only weeks before the end of the war. Only around two hundred enslaved soldiers were organized into service, but they were not sent into combat.

By the time the last Confederate soldiers surrendered to Union forces in June 1865, nearly 100,000 had been killed in combat or succumbed to wounds, more than 160,000 had died of disease, and roughly 30,000 had died in prison camps. (Wikipedia)

catDesc.term: Confederate States of America. Army. Mississippi. Infantry Regiment, 15th
catDesc.note:
Categories:
Military Units -- Federal Level: Confederate States Military

gloss.p: The 15th Regiment, Mississippi Infantry (Confederate) was organized on May 21, 1861 in Alcorn County, Mississippi under the command of Col. Winfield S. Statham and served in the Western Theater under Zollicoffer's and Bowen's Brigades. It was later commanded by Col. Michael Farrell. It was reorganized in May 1862 and consolidated into the 15th Regiment, Mississippi Consolidated Infantry on April 9, 1865 under the command of Lt. Col. Thomas B. Graham. (Howell, Jr., Military History of Mississippi, 21; Rowland, Official and Statistical Register of Mississippi, 614-620; National Park Service-Battle Units)

catDesc.term: Confederate States of America. Army. Mississippi. Infantry Regiment, 15th. Company K (Choctaw Greys)
catDesc.note:
Categories:
Military Units -- Federal Level: Confederate States Military

gloss.p: Commonly known as the Choctaw Greys, Company K of the 15th Regiment, Mississippi Infantry (Confederate) was organized on May 4, 1861 in Webster County, Mississippi under the command of Capt. Thomas B. Foard and served in the Western Theater. (Howell, Jr., Military History of Mississippi, 21; Rowland, Official and Statistical Register of Mississippi, 616)

div.p: I was at Banston on yesterday to fill the appointment of our friend Genl. A M. West and while there I had an interview with Capt. Wesson and some others of the Directors of the Miss Manufac-turing Company in regard to furnishing our soldiers with clotheing and such other articles as they might be able to let the State have for that purpose

Capt. Wesson informed me that he had received a letter from you and one from Col McAfee on the same subject and the meeting of the
Directory was being held for the purpose of useing the whole force of the factory for the benefit of the soldiers. and letting the planters take care of themselves. and that he thought that. the board would adopt that policy.

He also informed me that the usefullness of the Company had been very much impaired by the employees volunteering & going off to the army They were suffering greatly on account of the loss of their book keeper who was a volunteer.
div.note: James Haynes states he was in Banston. According to Ted Ownby, University of Mississippi, as found in Mississippi Encyclopedia (online), the name of the town was Bankston. "During the Civil War, the Mississippi Manufacturing Company made uniforms for Confederate troops from the state and took on the job of making shoes. Union troops burned down the company's building in 1865."

div.p: and a member of the Choctaw Guards which company is in the 15th Regiment.
Capt. Wesson gave his consent for the young man to go into the service and is contineuing his wages and retains his situation until the term of en-listment has ended.

I was informed that Mr P L Hallum the book keeper above alluded to was the manager of the interest of the company in the absence of Capt Wesson and if any thing knew more about its management than Captn W. himself. I suggested the proprity of getting the young man discharged and have him sent back again and told the Captain that I would write you on the subject.

If the company are going to sett their spindles to work for our soldiers, think that every facility facility for their successfull operation should be afforded them and I would therefore respectfully suggest to you to use your influence to have Mr Hallum discharged and sent back to the company—If the discharge should be granted it should be done in such a public manner. that the company of which he is a member. and the regiment should know the cause.—If he is more usefull at home than in the army he should certainly be sent back.

I am respectfully
Jas M Haynes
